reviewText: I have reviewed several of these.  They are wonderful for babies/toddlers who are unable to speak but can learn to ask for things or say things by "signing".  It is exciting for them to be able to communicate with adults in this manner.  My grandson loves to "say" please" and "thank you" and other words he would otherwise be unable to say.  He watches these over and over.  Of course repetition is necessary for them to learn the signing.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a wonderful video. I really can't say enough good things about it. My 12 month old picked up 3 signs from it very quickly. As someone who is not a fan of children watching a lot of videos or TV, I don't feel guilty letting her watch this. It goes slowly and is very simple. She loves it and so do we. It makes a great 1st birthday gift also!
summary: I agree, it is better than baby einstein!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought that teaching my baby to sign was silly.  At nine months I bought "first signs" for Ruth.  She couldn't have cared less.  She didn't like videos at all.  Before calling it a lost cause I tried again when she was around 12 months.Now, she will not eat a meal without "baby".  As a matter-of-fact, this is how we get her to eat an entire meal.  I sit with her and we watch baby signs.  I bought the other two videos (sharing signs and exploring signs) and we rotate them.  She can do most of the signs and understands them and uses them properly.  She is 16 months.  I am happy to say at 42 I can understand and use the signs properly as well...I only gave the video 4 stars because I do think that some of word choices are weird.  Why do we need to know the sign for dinosaur?  I'm sure someone needs it...not us.  However "hat" is more useful than I would have thought.  And sharing signs is great with "please" and "thank you".BOTTOM LINE:  My daughter is engaged and entertained and it probably has helped with her verbal communication as well as her non-verbal communication skills.  I highly recommend it.
summary: It bores me to tears but I'm not a baby...

reviewText: Highly entertaining video for my <1 yo son, with many visuals of both real animals and toys.  Good upbeat music also held his attention.

reviewText: This is a great tool to use for young children who are having speech delays like my grandson who is 22 months old.  He really likes this video...and it works well with his early intervention one on one.  I highly recommend it.  He picked up the signing so quickly...and also tries to say the words for each item.

reviewText: My daughter just turned one.  She loves watching this video.  Not only that but we started signing 2 weeks ago and she is already signing 9 words!!! We used the video in conjunction with flashcards and consistent use of the signs at home.  Our whole family is having fun learning and teaching our youngest!!  I would highly recommend this video!!!

reviewText: My children can sign as a result of this DVD.  We watch them daily and together we learned the signs.  At 14 months they sign: milk, cat, dog, hat, car, eat, more and a few others I can't think of.  They are real signs not the baby sign non sense that people are teaching their kids, which was important to me.  I don't teach them baby talk, why would I teach them "baby" sign?
Title: N/A

reviewText: The approach and editing of this DVD reminded us of Baby Einstein...they show, for example, a dog, then they show a very pretty Scandinavian woman smiling and doing the sign for "dog," then they might show footage of dog toys padding across the screen, then back to a real dog, all accompanied by favorites from classical music played in a scaled down way, probably electronically but sounding like xylophone, piano, etc. It's fun and well put together. LikeBaby Signing Time Volume 1 DVDit can be watched by any baby or infant--you don't have to have a goal of your infant learning to sign. I must say, though, that we likedBaby Signing Time Volume 1 DVDeven better--as my review for that product explains.
Title: N/A

reviewText: My daughter (18 months now!) loves this series.  She laughs and claps whenever I put it on.We started showing her the series at about 7 months but she didn't get interested until about 13 months.  I was shocked at how quickly she began making signs at that point.Some reviewers are critical about all the animal signs on this DVD but if you think about it, animals are VERY fascinating to children.  When you show this series to a baby, you aren't just teaching them important words for them to know (eat, milk, more, etc.) but are teaching them the actually concept of words and communication.  Getting them to keep watching by showing the animals and animal signs is helpful.  One of my daughter's first signs was dog and she was thrilled when she realized she had been able to make me understand her.  She learned additional signs rapidly after that breakthrough.Her verbal skills are expanding rapidly at this point but her pronunciation is still horrible - like most toddlers, only mommy and daddy can understand what she says.  Signing lets her get her point across much more easily so she feels far less frustrated.

reviewText: She loves the animal pictures and signs. It's great because the video does one animal then one action or daily use sign. For example, "cat" then "milk" then "dog" then "more". The animals keep her interested but I find the other words more useful for daily use so it works great for both of us. She gets so excited when I start this video!

reviewText: My 5 month old signed "milk" after watching this DVD about 6 times.  It is unbelievable that she can now communicate!!!  She had never been interested in any other baby DVD's I have purchased, but this transfixes her and she laughs and "talks" to the TV when this is on.  A must for any parent who wants their baby to be able to communicate before they can talk!

reviewText: This dvd is done very well.  We enjoy it.  My little girl is 18 months old, at the time of writing this, and we have been using Signing Time since she was 9 months.  She already uses quite a bit of signs (about 50).  I knew when I bought this dvd that most of these same signs we learned in Siging Time (Signing Time, by the way, is AWESOME.  We have all 6 dvd's and two music cd's and they are so great!!).  But I wanted another video, in addition to Signing Time, that would be fun for my little girl to watch and practice her signs.  She enjoyed the My Baby Can Talk clip (demo) of "cat" at the website so much that I wanted to add this to our growing ASL collection.On the Main Menu there is a Tutorial which is quite informative (especially if you are a beginner).  The first time we watched it, my daughter loved the video.  If it was a sign she knew, she was signing right along.  The pictures and live action are very nice and colorful.  The music is very nice.  The little baby, Jessica, is so adorable.Here's basically how it works:  They show a puppy and then Melissa (the signer on the video) shows the sign.  The word "puppy" is also shown on the screen.  Then you have lots of different puppy scenes (real puppies, toy puppies), etc.  Melissa will show the sign three times in all and Jessica (the little girl) signs each word once.  Sometimes there is a child's voice that will add an explanation to the sign.  As an example, for puppy the voice says, "like you are calling a dog" while Melissa pats her leg and signs puppy.  Sometimes they explain a sign by showing two outstreached hands (like if it were your hands out in front of you) and they show you how to place your hands for the sign (like for "drink", etc).  This was a nice feature, I thought.Jessica is young so she doesn't sign accurately yet.  That's ok.  This helps you see that babies don't have to sign it prefectly.  My baby signs many words that are not accurate yet.  For "daddy" she points to her head.  For "mommy" she points to her chin.  For "more" she touches both pointer fingers together.  In the My Baby Can Talk tutorial they even say that babies can't always do the sign correctly and might point for some signs.  It's just important that you keep signing the correct way and as she grows she will learn it more accurately.  At least you will know what she is talking about until then.Here's a list of the words taught in My Baby Can Talk First Signs (not in this order):bear, bird, book, bunny, butterfly, car, cat, cow, dinosaur, dog, drink, duck, eat, fish, go, horse, milk, more, mouse, shoes.The next dvd in the My Baby Can Talk series, as well as board books and flashcards, will be released later this year.  I look forward to buying more.  This first dvd in the series is nice to add to your ASL signing videos or a great one to have as your first one.  I do like it much better then Baby See N' Sign.  Be sure to check out the My Baby Can Talk website for a really nice online ASL dictionary.  You can also sign up for their free newsletter so you can get a notice when the other products will be available.Just as an added point, we have all 6 Signing Time dvd's and My Baby Can Talk dvd together on a shelf.  Each day I let my daughter choose one of them to watch.  She can go for days and only want to watch baby Jessica of My Baby Can Talk.  She really loves Signing Time also but goes in spurts liking one over the other for awhile.  I have written many other reviews so please read them too.
summary: Very nice dvd.  My baby loves it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am an experienced signing parent, having signed with my second son and am currently signing with my 20-month-old daughter. I have seen many signing videos over the last four years, both as a parent and as a professional in the baby signing industry. Upon viewing My Baby Can Talk™ - First Signs DVD for the first time, I was very impressed for a number of reasons.For starters, the movie itself is extremely engaging. I have my own little group of testers here in the house (three children) and I gauged their reactions carefully. My little girl, the youngest at 20 months, watched it the whole way through the first time with me by her side. She was able to connect the signs with the images on the screen quite easily with a little help from mom and genuinely enjoyed the footage of the animals the best (the panda having a snack is her favorite). I have not seen my daughter love a movie as much as she loves this one. She wants to watch it every day.I also thought that it is really great to show both an adult as well as a baby signing every sign. This is helpful in more than one way - children get to see another child in their age group signing and they also get to see the sign signed with more precision by an adult. The repetition in the movie is perfect as well as the variety of images shown. It really reinforces the sign.Love the classical music score, love the images, love the variety of signs ... all in all, 5 stars!
summary: Excellent DVD, fascinating for babies, easy to learn signs

reviewText: It is simply an audio-visual pleasure to watch it. For myself and my 3-year old, the signs are a welcome by-product of the DVD. The digital quality of the recording is absolutely the best in the market. The selection of the real images and toys are adorable; the segments of the classical music are designed specifically to appeal to children and adult alike and the rhymes in the video are very cute......

reviewText: My son loves to watch the video over and over again.  He's learned all of the signs and this video has also helped him to verbally identify objects as well.  He does not have a hearing disability, but I wanted him to be able to communicate with me as early as possible.  We started watching the videos when he was 10 months old and he learned quickly.  Now, he asks to watch the videos!  Great buy!

reviewText: A rave review!We started our daughter watching the video when she was a little over 5 or 6 months old while I would get ready for work. It kept her interested and occupied and I felt good about it because she was learning something. I then would start showing her signs like Go and Car and Milk and Sleep at that early age.By 9 months old our daughter, Campbell, was able to sign Butterfly and Fish (along with Go, Car and Milk)!  It was amazing. She caught on quite quickly to signing and we all enjoyed immensely!We had a lot of questions of why would teach our daughter to sign. Most people thought it was because she had a hearing problem!! She is now 16 months old and still signing and learning new ones I teach her. I don't think we encountered near the communication issues we would have if my daughter had not learned to sign at an early age. My job now is keep up with her signing!!!Your video is short, educational, easy to learn from and to the point!  I tell all parents about signing and we still get a lot of questions about it and more and more parents seem to be interested and I always steer them towards your videos and website. It has been a huge benefit to our family. Keep up the good work!

reviewText: This DVD is very well done. The images and the sounds are very good. I bought many DVDs for our child and this is by far the best. Buy it without hesitation.
